{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox officeholder |name =Mohammed Badie
{{lang|ar|محمد بديع}} |image = Mohammed_Badiea.jpg |office = 8th General Guide of the Egyptian [[Muslim Brotherhood]] |president = |term_start = 16 January 2010 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Mohammed Mahdi Akef]] |successor = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|8|7|df=y}} |birth_place = [[El Mahalla El Kubra]], [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]] |death_date = |death_place = |religion = [[Sunni Islam]] |otherparty = |alma_mater = [[Cairo University]] |spouse = |children = Ammar
and three others }} '''Mohammed Badie''' ({{lang-ar|محمد بديع}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Muḥammad Badīʿ}}'', {{IPA-arz|mæˈħæmmæd bæˈdiːʕ|IPA}}; born 7 August 1943) is the eighth Supreme Guide of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]].{{cite news |url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/muslim-brotherhood-decision-participate-friday-protest-preserve-unity |title=Muslim Brotherhood: Decision to participate in Friday protest is to preserve unity |work=Egypt Independent |date=9 October 2010 |accessdate=9 December 2012}} He has headed the Egyptian branch of the international Muslim Brotherhood organization since 2010. Before becoming general guide, Badie had been a member of the group's governing council, the Guidance Bureau, since 1996. He was arrested by Egyptian authorities on 20 August 2013.{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-egypt-muslim-brotherhoods-spiritual-leader-arrested-20130820,0,7835837.story |title=Egypt arrests Muslim Brotherhood leader |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=20 August 2013 |accessdate=20 August 2013}} On 28 April 2014, after an eight-minute trial{{Cite news |author=[[Patrick Cockburn|Cockburn, Patrick]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/the-death-of-justice-in-egypt-an-eightminute-trial-no-arguments-for-the-defence-and-683-sentenced-to-death-9298908.html |title=The Death of Justice in Egypt |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=28 April 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} in which Badie could not present his defence, he was sentenced to death, along with 682 others who are allegedly Muslim Brotherhood supporters.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-27186339 |title=Egypt: Mass death sentence on Islamists passed |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=28 April 2014 |accessdate=12 July 2014}} He was sentenced to life in prison on 15 September 2014,{{Cite news |url=http://www.madamasr.com/content/badie-and-14-mb-leaders-sentenced-life-giza-clashes |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140915172513/http://www.madamasr.com/content/badie-and-14-mb-leaders-sentenced-life-giza-clashes |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 September 2014 |title=Badie and 14 MB leaders sentenced to life for Giza clashes |publisher=Mada Masr |date=15 September 2014 |accessdate=15 September 2014 }} and was sentenced to death on 11 April 2015, along with thirteen other senior Muslim Brotherhood members.{{cite web | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/mohamed-badie-leader-of-muslim-brotherhood-sentenced-to-death-in-egypt-1.3029244 | title=Mohamed Badie, leader of Muslim Brotherhood, sentenced to death in Egypt | work=CBC News | date=11 April 2015 | accessdate=11 April 2015 | author=Reuters}} He received a sixth life sentence on 22 August 2015{{cite news|title=Egyptian MB Leader Sentenced|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-08-22/egyptian-brotherhood-leader-handed-sixth-life-prison-sentence/6717748|accessdate=24 August 2015|agency=ABC Australia|date=22 August 2015}} and a seventh on 8 May 2017.{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood’s Supreme Guide Mohammed Badie sentenced to life in prison|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2017/05/08/Muslims-Brotherhood-leader-Mohammed-Badie-sentenced-to-life-in-prison.html|work=Al Arabiya|date=8 May 2016}} ==Biography== ===Early life=== Badie was born on 7 August 1943 in the industrial city of [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra|Mahalla al-Kubra]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/whos-who-in-the-muslim-brotherhood#MuhammadBadie |title=Who's Who in Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood |date=September 2012 |publisher=[[Washington Institute for Near East Policy]] |accessdate=13 July 2014}} He received a degree in veterinary medicine at Cairo in 1965.[http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=22669 Profile of Dr Badie: A resilient leader] Ikhwan, Retrieved 25 January 2011. The same year, he was arrested for the first time for his political activity in the Muslim Brotherhood, along with Muslim Brotherhood leader [[Sayyed Qutb]], during a nationwide roundup of activists; he was sentenced to 15 years in prison by a military tribunal. After 9 years, he was paroled along with almost all other Brotherhood prisoners in 1974 by the Egyptian president, [[Anwar El Sadat|Anwar al-Sadat]]. Badi'e went on to continue his studies and begin a teaching career at various Egyptian universities. He became a part-time professor of pathology at the veterinary school of [[Beni Suef]] University. ===2013 crisis, arrest, and trials=== In July 2013, Egyptian president [[Mohammed Morsi]], member of the Muslim Brotherhood, was removed by a [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|coup d'état]] after the [[June 2013 Egyptian protests|June protests]]. A travel ban was put on Badie as well as Badie's deputy Khairat el-Shater.{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/07/03/egypt-teeters-on-brink-overthrow-as-army-deadline-is-set-to-expire |title=Morsi reportedly being held hours after being ousted as Egypt's president |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date=3 July 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} Badie's arrest was ordered on 10 July 2013 for "inciting the violence in Cairo on Monday in which more than 50 people were killed."{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-23256937 |title=Egypt Muslim Brotherhood leader Mohamed Badie arrest ordered |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=10 July 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} On 14 July 2013 Egypt's military-installed prosecutor general [[Hisham Barakat]] ordered his assets to be frozen.{{Cite news |title=Asset freeze for Islamist leaders goes into action |url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/asset-freeze-islamist-leaders-goes-action |work=Egypt Independent |date=15 July 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2013}} Badie was arrested on 20 August 2013.{{Cite news |title=VIDEO: Muslim Brotherhood Supreme Guide Badie arrested |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/79488.aspx |work=[[Ahram Online]] |date=19 August 2013 |accessdate=19 August 2013}}{{Cite news |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/08/20/Egyp-st-Muslim-Brotherhood-Supreme-Guide-Mohamed-Badie-arrested.html |title=Egypt's Brotherhood General Guide Mohammad Badie detained |publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] |date=20 August 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} His two deputies were also arrested and he was due to stand trial on 25 August.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/20/egypt-badie-muslim-brotherhood-detained |title=Egypt: Muslim Brotherhood leader Mohammed Badie reported detained |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=20 August 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/25-egyptian-police-recruits-gunned-down-by-militants-in-sinai-mubarak-could-be-released/2013/08/19/dc77447e-08bf-11e3-8974-f97ab3b3c677_story.html?hpid=z1 |title=Egypt arrests Brotherhood spiritual leader; Mubarak could be released |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=19 August 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} Badie was succeeded as the Muslim Brotherhood's Supreme Guide by [[Mahmoud Ezzat (Muslim Brotherhood)|Mahmoud Ezzat]] on a temporary basis.{{Cite news |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/08/21/Mahmoud-Ezzat-named-Muslim-Brotherhood-s-new-leader.html |title=Mahmoud Ezzat named Muslim Brotherhood’s new leader |publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] |date=20 August 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} Badie then has been tried in the following cases: * Together with eighteen other defendants, he has been accused at [[Cairo]] Criminal Court of inciting the murder of nine protesters who stormed the Brotherhood's Cairo [[headquarters]] on 30 June. On 29 October 2013, a three-judge panel stepped down from the proceedings, citing "uneasiness" over the trial as trial proceedings were disrupted by named defendants.{{Cite news |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2013/10/29/judges-in-egyptianbrotherhoodtrialquit.html |title=Judges in Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood trial quit |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |date=29 October 2013 |accessdate=10 February 2014}} On 11 December 2013, a second panel of judges withdrew from the trial.{{Cite news |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/88855/Egypt/Politics-/Second-judging-panel-withdraws-from-Brotherhood-tr.aspx |title=Second judging panel withdraws from Brotherhood trial |publisher=[[Ahram Online]] |date=11 December 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} * On 7 June 2014, 47 defendants (ten of them ''in absentia'') including Badie were tried at the Criminal Court of [[Shubra el-Kheima]] for inciting murder and violence, cutting off roads, threatening public order, and resisting authorities, especially referring to a demonstration in the town of [[Qalyub]] in July 2013 (notably blocking a highway),{{Cite news |url=http://thecairopost.com/news/108396/news/badies-qalyub-highway-case-postponed-to-may-7 |title=Badie's 'Qalyub highway' case postponed to May 7 |last= |first= |newspaper=[[The Cairo Post]] |date=29 April 2014 |accessdate=16 July 2014 }} in the course of which at least two people were killed. Along with nine others, Badie was sentenced to death, while there was no sentence yet for additional 37 defendants in the case.{{Cite news |url=http://www.madamasr.com/content/mb-supreme-guide-nine-others-sentenced-death-qalyub-case |title=MB supreme guide, nine others sentenced to death in Qalyub case |last= |first= |publisher=[[Mada Masr]] |date=7 June 2014 |accessdate=16 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140725201234/http://www.madamasr.com/content/mb-supreme-guide-nine-others-sentenced-death-qalyub-case |archivedate=25 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }} On 5 July 2014 ten of them were sentenced to death by the [[Banha]] Criminal Court, the remaining including Badie to life in prison.{{Cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/07/05/world/meast/egypt-mohammed-badie-sentenced/ |title=Muslim Brotherhood leader, 36 others sentenced to life in Cairo |author=Mitra Mobasherat |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=5 July 2014 |accessdate=16 July 2014 }} * On 15 July 2013, five persons died in clashes in [[Giza]], notably in the ''Al-Bahr Al-Azam'' area near a police building. On 8 September 2013, Egypt’s prosecutor-general referred Badie and 14 others to the criminal court, accusing them of being responsible for the incidents.{{Cite news |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/81105/Egypt/Politics-/Brotherhoods-Badie-referred-to-criminal-court-for-.aspx |title=Brotherhood's Badie referred to criminal court for Giza clashes |publisher=[[Ahram Online]] |date=8 September 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014 }}{{Cite news |url=http://cairoinformer.com/31118/badie-beltagy-and-erian-referred-to-criminal-court-over-al-bahr-al-azam-clashes/ |title=Badie, Beltagy and Erian referred to criminal court over al-Bahr al-Azam clashes |publisher=[[Cairo Informer]] |date=9 September 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014 }} Several trial sessions were reported in the news,{{Cite web |url=http://thecairopost.com/news/110168/news/badies-bahr-al-azam-trial-adjourned |title=Badie's Bahr Al-Azam trial adjourned |publisher=[[The Cairo Post]] |date=12 May 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014 }} until on 19 June 2014, [[Giza]] Criminal Court sentenced Badie, Muslim Brotherhood senior members [[Mohamed Beltagy]] and [[Essam el-Erian]], as well as 11 others to death for inciting violence.{{Cite web |url=http://www.madamasr.com/content/mb-supreme-guide-13-others-sentenced-death-istiqama-clashes |title=MB supreme guide, 13 others sentenced to death for Istiqama clashes |last= |first= |website=[[Mada Masr]] |date=19 June 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140719201546/http://www.madamasr.com/content/mb-supreme-guide-13-others-sentenced-death-istiqama-clashes |archivedate=19 July 2014 |df=dmy-all }}{{Cite news |url=http://www.canada.com/news/Leader+Egypts+Muslim+Brotherhood+sentenced+death+second+time/9954638/story.html |title=Leader of Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood sentenced to death for a second time |publisher=[[Canada.com]] |date=19 June 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160124031145/http://www.canada.com/news/Leader+Egypts+Muslim+Brotherhood+sentenced+death+second+time/9954638/story.html |archivedate=24 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }} * In an eight-minute trial without an opportunity for a defense on 28 April 2014, Badie and 682 others were found guilty and sentenced to die by judge Said Youssef in a court in [[Minya, Egypt|Minya]], referring to an attack on a police station in the [[Minya Governorate]] on 14 August 2013 when 11 policemen and 2 civilians were killed. The same judge confirmed the death sentence on 21 June 2014 in 183 cases,{{Cite news |url=http://www.n24.de/n24/Nachrichten/Politik/d/4944176/183-islamisten-zum-tode-verurteilt.html |title=Ägypten: 183 Islamisten zum Tode verurteilt |language=de |website=[[N24 (Germany)|N24]] |date=21 June 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} including Badie's.{{Cite news |url=http://thecairopost.com/news/117447/news/badie-sentenced-to-life-in-prison-over-blocking-road |title=Badie sentenced to life in prison over blocking road |publisher=[[The Cairo Post]] |date=5 July 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014}}{{Cite news |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/egypt-confirms-180-islamist-death-sentences |title=Egypt court confirms death sentences for over 180 |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=21 June 2014 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} Two months later, Egypt's [[Grand Mufti of Egypt|Grand Mufti]] commuted the death sentence to a life sentence for Badie and five others. Egyptian law requires any capital sentence to be referred to the Grand Mufti, the highest Islamist religious authority, for an opinion before any execution can take place.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/death-sentence-badie-reduced-life-20148305040329928.html|title=Badie death sentence reduced to life in Egypt|last=|first=|date=30 August 2014|website=Aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-08-04}} * In a 2015 trial, a Cairo court sentenced Badie and 18 other prominent Brotherhood figures to life in prison over an attack on a police station in 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/08/life-terms-egypt-badie-18-brotherhood-members-150822103759000.html|title=Badie receives latest life sentence from Egypt court|last=|first=|date=22 Aug 2015|website=Aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-08-04}} Charges ranged from murder and inciting violence to stealing weapons and destruction of public and private property. The court also handed the same sentence to 76 others ''in absentia''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/muslim-brotherhood-leader-mohamed-badie-sentenced-to-life-in-prison-on-top-of-death-sentence-10467167.html|title=Muslim Brotherhood leader sentenced to life in prison - on top of existing death sentence|date=2015-08-22|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-08-04|language=en-GB}} * In 2016, an Egyptian court also sentenced Badie and 35 other people to life imprisonment for inciting violence in the Suez Canal city of Ismailia that led to the killing of three people in July 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/05/mohamed-badie-muslim-brotherhood-egypt-160530143709911.html|title=Mohamed Badie among dozens sentenced for life in Egypt|last=|first=|date=30 May 2016|website=Aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-08-04}} * In 2017, Egypt's Court of Cassation accepted the appeal of Badie and 49 other defendants against the death sentences received for the 2013 police station attacks. The court ordered a retrial for the charges.{{Cite news|url=https://dailynewsegypt.com/2017/05/10/cassation-court-orders-retrial-badie-49-others/|title=Cassation Court orders retrial of Badie, 49 others|last=|first=|date=10 May 2017|work=Daily News Egypt|access-date=3 Aug 2017}} * Badie returned to court in Giza in 2017 to face charges of "preparing an operations room to confront the state and create chaos in the country following the dismantling of the [[August 2013 Rabaa massacre|Rabaa al-Adawiya sit-in]]" and "planning to burn public property and churches", and he received another life sentence.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/egypt-issues-life-sentence-muslim-brotherhood-chief-170508151622974.html|title=Egypt issues life sentence for Muslim Brotherhood chief|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2017-08-04}} ==Statements == ===Israel=== In a weekly [[sermon]], titled "How Islam Confronts the Oppression and Tyranny [against the Muslims]," Mohammed Badie accused the Arab and Muslim regimes of avoiding confrontation with "the [[Zionist]] entity" and the [[United States]], and also of disregarding "[[Allah|Allah's]] commandment to wage jihad for His sake with [their] money and [their] lives, so that Allah's word will reign supreme and the [[infidel]]s' word will be inferior." Badie stated that the U.S. is immoral and doomed to collapse. He accused the [[Palestinian Authority]] of "selling out" the [[State of Palestine|Palestinian]] cause, adding that a third [[:wikt:intifada|intifada]] was about to erupt. Badie also stated that "Resistance is the only solution against the Zio-American arrogance and tyranny, and all we need is for the Arab and Muslim peoples to stand behind it and support it."{{cite web |title=Muslim Brotherhood Supreme Guide: 'The U.S. Is Now Experiencing the Beginning of Its End'; Improvement and Change in the Muslim World 'Can Only Be Attained Through Jihad and Sacrifice' |url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/4650.htm |work=MEMRI |accessdate=10 July 2012 |date=6 October 2010}}{{cite news |title=Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood leader: Israelis are rapists of Jerusalem |url=http://www.israelhayom.com/site/newsletter_article.php?id=4983 |accessdate=10 July 2012 |newspaper=Israel Hayom |date=9 July 2012}}{{cite web |title=Terrorism: Muslim Brotherhood |publisher=Jewish Virtual Library |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Terrorism/muslimbrotherhood.html |accessdate=10 July 2012}}{{Failed verification|date=August 2013}} In July 2012, during his weekly sermon, Mohammed Badie stated that [[Israelis]] are "rapists" of [[Jerusalem]], and called on all Muslims to "wage [[jihad]] with their money and their selves to free [[al-Quds]]." He described the creation of Israel in international law as an "alleged, illusory right."{{cite news |title=Muslim Brotherhood Leader Calls Israelis Rapists |url=http://www.algemeiner.com/2012/07/09/egypt%E2%80%99s-muslim-brotherhood-leader-calls-israelis-rapists/ |accessdate=10 July 2012 |newspaper=The Algemeiner |date=9 July 2012}}{{cite news |last=Schwartz |first=Sharona |title=Egyptian Muslim Brotherhood’s Leader Says Jihad on Israel Is Every Muslim's Duty |url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/egyptian-muslim-brotherhood%E2%80%99s-leader-says-jihad-on-israel-is-every-muslim%E2%80%99s-duty/ |accessdate=10 July 2012 |newspaper=The Blaze |date=8 July 2012}} In October 2012, Badie alleged that "The Jews have dominated the land, spread corruption on earth, spilled the blood of believers and in their actions profaned holy places, including their own." As such, he demanded that the Arab world reject negotiations with Israel in favour of "holy Jihad," saying that "the Zionists only understand force" and while alleging that allowing Jews to pray on the [[Temple Mount]], Judaism's holiest site, would result in the destruction of the [[Al-Aqsa Mosque]].{{cite news |last=Miller |first=Elhanan |title='Holy Jihad' is the only way to deal with Israel, says Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood chief |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/holy-jihad-is-the-only-way-to-deal-with-israel-says-egypts-muslim-brotherhood-chief/ |accessdate=11 October 2012 |newspaper=The Times of Israel |date=11 October 2012}} ===Operation Pillar of Defense=== Badei denounced peace efforts with Israel, urging holy war against Israel, on 22 November 2012—just a day after Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi succeeded in brokering a truce to end eight days of Israel-Hamas [[fighting]]. Badei says "jihad is obligatory" for Muslims and that peace deals with Israel are a "game of grand deception." He says there's been enough negotiations, the "enemy knows nothing but the language of force."{{Cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/t/story/egypt-brotherhood-leader-blasts-peace-israel-17785651 |title=Egypt Brotherhood Leader Blasts Peace with Israel |agency=Associated Press, |publisher=ABC News |date=22 November 2012 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} ===Overthrow of Mohamed Morsi=== In July 2013, Badei condemned the removal of Egyptian president [[Mohamed Morsi]] by the Egyptian military stating "I swear by God that what [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi|(Gen. Abdel-Fattah) al-Sissi]] did in Egypt is more criminal than if he had carried an axe and demolished the holy [[Kaaba]], stone by stone."{{Cite news |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/07/26/MB-leader-Mursi-ouster-worse-than-destroying-Islam-s-holiest-shrine-.html |title=MB leader: Mursi's ouster worse than destroying Islam's holiest shrine |publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] |date=25 July 2013 |accessdate=15 July 2014}} ==Personal life== Badie has four children, three daughters and a son.{{cite news |title=Son of Brotherhood's Supreme Guide shot dead, house set ablaze |url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/son-brotherhood-s-supreme-guide-shot-dead-house-set-ablaze |accessdate=17 August 2013 |newspaper=Egypt Independent |date=17 August 2013}} His son, Ammar, was killed in [[Political violence in Egypt (2013)|the clashes]] in Cairo on 16 August 2013. ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== *{{Aljazeeratopic|person/mohammed-badie}} *[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/english-free-tags/mohamed-badie Mohammed Badie] collected news and commentary at ''[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]'' {{s-start}} {{s-rel}} {{s-bef|before=[[Mohammed Mahdi Akef]]}} {{s-ttl|title=General Guide of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]]|years=2010–present}} {{s-inc}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Badie, Mohamed}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Egyptian Muslim Brotherhood leaders]] [[Category:Egyptian democracy activists]] [[Category:Islamic democracy activists]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment by Egypt]] [[Category:People of the Egyptian revolution of 2011]] [[Category:2013 Egyptian coup d'état]]

{{Use Indian English|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = Nari Contractor | image = | caption = | fullname = Nariman Jamshedji Contractor | batting = Left-hand bat | bowling = Right-arm medium | columns = 2 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1934|3|7|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Godhra]], [[Gujarat]], [[India]] | column1 = [[Test cricket|Tests]] | matches1 = 31 | runs1 = 1611 | bat avg1 = 31.58 | 100s/50s1 = 1/11 | top score1 = 108 | deliveries1 = 186 | wickets1 = 1 | bowl avg1 = 80.00 | fivefor1 = – | tenfor1 = – | best bowling1 = 1/9 | catches/stumpings1= 18/- | column2 = [[First-class cricket|First-class]] | matches2 = 138 | runs2 = 8611 | bat avg2 = 39.86 | 100s/50s2 = 22/- | top score2 = 176 | deliveries2 = 2026 | wickets2 = 26 | bowl avg2 = 40.00 | fivefor2 = – | tenfor2 = – | best bowling2 = 4/85 | catches/stumpings2= 72/- | international = true | country = India | testdebutfor = | testdebutagainst = New Zealand | testdebutdate = 2 December | testdebutyear = 1955 | lasttestdate = 7 March | lasttestfor = | lasttestagainst = West Indies | lasttestyear = 1962 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/player/27667.html ESPNcricinfo | date = 10 January | year = 2013 }}
'''Nariman Jamshedji "Nari" Contractor''' {{audio|Nari_Contractor.ogg|pronunciation}} (born 7 March 1934, [[Godhra]], [[Gujarat]]) is a former [[cricket]] player, who was a left-handed opening [[batsman]]. His professional career finished after a serious injury.
==Cricket career== Contractor began his [[first-class cricket|first-class]] career, playing for the [[Gujarat]]. The captain of Gujarat Phiroz Khambata saw how Nari played in the selection trial matches for [[MCA's Silver Jubilee]] matches in 1955. He did well in the trials and expected to be selected for the matches against Pakistan Services & Bhawalpur Cricket Association. He got to the team because Captain Kambatha had dropped out. Contractor scored hundreds in both innings of his debut, becoming the second man after [[Arthur Morris]] to do so.<ref name="toi">{{cite web |last1=Waingankar |first1=Makarand |authorlink1=Makarand Waingankar |title=Nari Contractor: The man who laughed at his own misfortune |url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/new-zealand-in-india-2016/top-stories/Nari-Contractor-The-man-who-laughed-at-his-own-misfortune/articleshow/12697426.cms |website=The Times of India |date=17 April 2012}}</ref>
Later he was chosen to play for India. Nari became an opener after one of the players [[Vinoo Mankad]] couldn't take part in a Test match against New Zealand at [[Delhi]] in 1955.<ref name="toi"/> Later he became an Indian captain.
At [[Lord's]] in 1959, he broke two ribs in the first innings by [[Brian Statham]], despite which he scored 81. Later in the year, his 74 in the second innings at Kanpur was crucial in India winning its first Test against Australia. This innings ended when he pulled [[Alan Keith Davidson|Alan Davidson]], who was bowling left-arm spin at the time. [[Neil Harvey]] at short leg ducked and turned, but the ball got stuck between his legs.
==Injury and consequences==
Contractor led India to a [[English cricket team in India in 1961–62|series win against England]] in 1961–62 and captained the side to [[Indian cricket team in West Indies in 1961–62|Caribbean the same season]]. There, in a tour match against [[Barbados national cricket team|Barbados]] at the [[Kensington Oval]] in [[Bridgetown]], in March 1962, he was on 2 [[not out]] while opening the batting with [[Dilip Sardesai]] during his side's first innings,<ref>{{cite web |title=Barbados v Indians, India in West Indies 1961/62 |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/25/25347.html |website=CricketArchive |accessdate=31 July 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304215823/http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/25/25347.html |archivedate=4 March 2016}}</ref> when his attention was for a moment distracted as he faced [[Charlie Griffith]] in the fourth ball of the second over. He saw somebody open a window in the [[Cricket pavilion|pavilion]], and consequently was unable concentrate on the ball following its delivery by Griffith, seeing the ball "just inches away before it hit" him.<ref name="ParsiKhabar">{{cite web |title=Nari Contractor: ‘I don’t mind living it all over again’ |url=http://parsikhabar.net/individuals/nari-contractor-i-dont-mind-living-it-all-over-again/1443 |website=Parsi Khabar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623100513/http://parsikhabar.net:80/individuals/nari-contractor-i-dont-mind-living-it-all-over-again/1443/ |archivedate=23 June 2010 |date=7 March 2009}}</ref> Contractor took a blow at the back of his skull<ref name=mid-nari>{{cite news |url=http://www.mid-day.com/sports/2012/mar/200312-sports-50-years-on-Nari-recalls-near-fatal-blow.htm |author=Murzello, Clayton |title=50 years on, Nari recalls near fatal blow |work=Mid-Day |date=20 March 2012 |accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> fracturing it. A blood clot had developed inside his skull and pressing against the brain paralyzing him from the waist down. Two surgeries were performed to remove the clot. Requiring [[blood transfusion]] for the purpose, the West Indies captain [[Frank Worrell]] donated blood,<ref>{{cite web |last1=de Silva |first1=A. C. |title=Frank Worrell donated blood to save Indian Nari Contractor's life |url=http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2010/01/03/spo36.asp |publisher=[[Sunday Observer (Sri Lanka)|Sunday Observer]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106050942/http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2010/01/03/spo36.asp |archivedate=6 January 2010 |date=3 January 2010}}</ref> alongside Contractor's teammates [[Chandu Borde]], [[Bapu Nadkarni]] and [[Polly Umrigar]].<ref>{{cite newspaper |title=Contractor has 2nd Operation By Brain Specialist |accessdate=31 July 2018 |newspaper=The Indian Express |agency=Press Trust of India |date=20 March 1962 |page=20}}</ref> Contractor's life was saved but his international career was abruptly ended as a result. In a recent interview, he mentioned as his only regret that he wanted play just ''one'' Test after the injury, but people did not want him to.<ref name="ParsiKhabar"/>
At the time Contractor was seriously injured, cricket batsmen did not wear helmets. They do now.
During his playing days, Contractor was considered a glamour boy of Indian cricket. In an interview with [[Simi Garewal]] in 1999, former Tamil Nadu chief minister [[Jayalalithaa]] stated that as a school girl she had a crush on Contractor.
==Present time==
Contractor now lives in [[Mumbai]] where he coaches at the [[Cricket Club of India]] Academy. He received the C.K. Nayudu Lifetime Achievement Award in 2007.<ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/sport/cricket/article2054130.ece C.K. Nayudu Lifetime Achievement Award for Durrani] Retrieved 26 March 2014.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{other uses|Nikola Vukčević (disambiguation)}} '''Nikola Vukčević''' is a [[Montenegrins (ethnic group)|Montenegrin]] [[film director]], born on 19 August 1974,<ref name=IMDB>{{cite web|last=IMDB|title=Nikola Vukcevic|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1451640/|accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> in [[Podgorica]], [[SR Montenegro]], [[Yugoslavia]].<ref name=IMDB /><ref name=Crew>{{cite web|last=Galileo Production|title=Galileo Production Crew|url=http://www.galileoproduction.info/stranica.php?akcija=crew|accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> He is a stage and film director, independent producer since 1995, member of Film board of [[Montenegrin Academy of Sciences and Arts]]<ref name=IMDB /> (CANU), and professor at national Faculty of Dramatic Arts – Cetinje. Also, Artistic director at City theatre Podgorica, since 2004.<ref name=Crew />
==Biography== {{advertisement|date=January 2018}} Vukcevic is the creative director of Podgorica City Theatre (2003-), professor of Film Directing module at the Department of Film Directing at the Montenegrin National Faculty of Drama Cetinje (FDU Cetinje). Also, Vukcevic is the youngest member ever to join the Film Board of the National Academy of Arts and Science (CANU).
Vukcevic worked as the director/ author in around 80 projects, including one feature film (''[[A View from the Eiffel Tower]]'',<ref name=Crew /> presented at around 30 international festivals; for a selected list please see the attached factsheet), ten theatre performances, (performed and awarded at a number of important festivals, i.e. Budva Theatre City, Infant, Exit, TIBA, etc.) He also directed four short films, one TV film (shown on many festivals and televisions inside country and abroad), 25 half-an-hour documentaries for Montenegrin Broadcasting Service TV CG, as well as numerous music videos, commercials, TV clips.
(since 2004) - Vukcevic is at the position of Artistic director of City Theatre Podgorica<ref name=Crew /> (second important theatre in state of Montenegro, after its National theatre), and artistic head of new productions, with more than 25 stage productions in charge (since 2003). Vukcevic is well versed in the use of modern cinematic technology, a skill he learned through collaboration with experienced production and postproduction crews (including Arkadena – Slovenia, Vizije – Croatia) as well as through attendance of international festivals, workshops and training sessions. Also, Vukcevic owns a majority in film company GALILEO PRODUCTION MONTENEGRO,<ref name=Crew /> which deals with film & video production, advertising, advertising, promotional films etc.
He has been awarded with many national and foreign awards. Nikola Vukcevic is married and a father of two children.
Vukcevic’s projects have been seen by a wide international audiences – in the last five years his films and plays have been performed/screened at more than 40 international film and theatre festivals. His work has earned him the status of one of the best known and respected theatre and film directors of his generation in Montenegro. He is also the youngest professor of film direction at a national Drama Faculty on the Balkans – a status that he specially covets.
Nikola Vukcevic has been named an Ambassador of Montenegrin Culture by the EU's Directorate General Enlargement. The Directorate is a project set up to promote the countries applying for membership of European Union, and the Ambassadors of culture will represent their country during the accession.
His next film project ''The Boys from Marksa I Engels Street'' is the winner of the 2nd award by the Ministry of Culture of Montenegro's programme for cinema 2010. The project has been awarded 60,000 Euro financial assistance.
==Education==
Vukcevic received a Bachelor of Arts in Film and Theatre Directing from the Academy of Arts Novi Sad, Yugoslavia,<ref name=IMDB /> studying under supervision of internationally acclaimed film and theatre director [[Vlatko Gilic]] (films on Cannes film festival – 1973, 1977, 1980; Berlin, Oberhauzen, Moscow, New York ...), as Student of Generation 1998 from Drama section, and he has finished his Faculty – one year before deadline. Vukcevic has been included in category of the best University students in Novi Sad. In June 2001 he received a master's degree of Arts in drama. His thesis was awarded and published as a book "I [http://www.allbookstores.com/Uticaj-Filma-Pozoriste-Novih-Formi/9788649501782 Influence of Film On Theatre of New Forms]". Since November 2010 Vukcevic has PhD, on cinematic and theatre poetics of Ingmar Bergman.
''A View from the Eiffel tower'' had a modest production budget of only 30 000 Euro. Its cast however included some of the most known actors from ex Yugoslavia who agreed to work on a voluntary basis or for very reduced fees. This was the first Montenegrin film after a fifteen-year break. Also, ''A View from the Eiffel tower'' was the first co-production of companies from ex Yugoslavia, Montenegro, Croatia, Slovenia and Serbia.

{{Infobox serial killer | name= Paul Durousseau | image= Paul Durousseau.jpg | caption=Durousseau's mug shot | birthname= Paul Durousseau | alias=The Jacksonville Strangler | birth_date={{Birth date and age|1970|08|11}} | birth_place=[[Beaumont, Texas]], U.S. | height=6 ft 6 in (1.98 m) | victims=7+ | country=[[United States|U.S.]], possibly [[Germany]] | states=[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Florida]] | beginyear=January 6, 1997 | endyear=January 20, 2003 | apprehended=June 17, 2003 | penalty=[[Capital punishment|Death]] }}
'''Paul Durousseau''' (born August 11, 1970)<ref name="DOC">{{cite web |url=http://www.dc.state.fl.us/ActiveInmates/inmateaction.asp?DataAction=GetInmate&DCNumber=J19087 |title=Inmate Population Information Detail - Paul Durousseau |publisher=[[Florida Department of Corrections]] |accessdate=February 6, 2010 }}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[serial killer]] who [[murder]]ed seven young women (including two who were [[pregnant]]) in the southeastern United States between 1997 and 2003. [[Germany|German]] authorities suspect he may have killed several local women when he was stationed there with the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] during the early 1990s. Typically, Durousseau would gain the victim's trust, enter the victim's home, tie their hands, [[rape]], then [[Strangling|strangle]] them to death.<ref name="radford">Ferguson, George, Emily Downing, Kaylor Eutsler, & David Disque. [http://maamodt.asp.radford.edu/Psyc%20405/serial%20killers/Durousseau,%20Paul%20_Fall,%202006_.pdf ''Paul Durousseau: The Jacksonville Serial Killer''.] Radford University Dept of Psychology.</ref> All of his known victims were young, single [[African-American]] women.
== Personal life == Paul Durousseau was born in [[Beaumont, Texas|Beaumont]], [[Texas]]. In 1971, he moved in with his mother's family in [[Los Angeles]] after his father, unwed to his mother, deserted them. Little else is known publicly about Durousseau's childhood. After graduating high school, 19-year-old Durousseau found himself working as a security guard. His first offenses as an adult took place on December 18, 1991 and January 21, 1992 for [[Concealed carry in the United States|carrying a concealed firearm]] in [[California]].<ref name="jacksonville.com">{{cite web | last = Chapin | first = Veronica | title = Cabdriver arrested in 6 serial killings | work = jacksonville.com | publisher = The Florida Times-Union | date = 18 June 2003 | url = http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/061803/met_12819930.shtml | accessdate = }}</ref>
In November 1992, Durousseau enlisted in the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]]<ref name="jacksonville.com"/> and was stationed in [[Germany]], where he met Natoca, who would later become his wife. The two married in 1995 in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]]. In 1996, they were transferred to [[Fort Benning]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. On March 13, 1997, Durousseau was arrested for [[kidnapping]] and [[Rape|raping]] a young woman. However, in August of that year he was cleared of those charges. Soon after, he was found in possession of stolen goods. He was [[court-martial]]ed in January 1999, found guilty and [[Dishonorable discharge#Dishonorable|dishonorably discharged]] from the Army.<ref name="trutv.com">{{cite web | last =Bell | first =Rachael | title =Paul Durousseau, the Jacksonville Serial Killer | work =Crime Library | publisher =truTV | date = | url =http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/paul_durousseau/index.html | accessdate =6 April 2013}}</ref>{{rp|3}}
Durousseau and his wife moved to [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], [[Florida]], where they had two daughters. It was during that period that he committed most of the murders. He struggled to keep jobs and make ends meet, and the couple would often have fights over the issue of finances. In 1999, the police advised Durousseau's wife on how to file for a [[restraining order]] after he allegedly slapped her in the face and grabbed her by the neck. Later, she testified he got violently angry when she talked about getting a [[divorce]]. In September and October 2001, Durousseau spent 48 days in jail for [[Domestic violence|domestic battery]].<ref name="trutv.com"/>
Durousseau still managed to hold various legitimate jobs. In 2001, he was hired as a school bus driver and an animal control worker despite being a convicted felon. In 2003, he worked as a [[Taxicab|taxi]] driver and it is now accepted that this is how he first came into contact with some of his victims. It was erroneously reported that Gator City Taxi Company failed to run a background check on Durousseau;<ref>{{cite news| url=http://jacksonville.bizjournals.com/jacksonville/stories/2003/07/21/story4.html | first=Paul | last=Ivice | publisher=Jacksonville Business Journal |title=Gator City Taxi sued in 3 deaths | date=July 21, 2003}}</ref> the City of Jacksonville was responsible for the background check, and issued Durousseau's taxi driver permit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.coj.net/departments/parking-facilities-and-enforcement/motor-vehicle-inspections.aspx |title=Vehicle For Hire and Driver Certifications |website=coj.net |publisher= |accessdate=October 10, 2014}}</ref>
Neighbors and friends described Durousseau as a "lewd womanizer". He often asked young women when they planned to "make flicks" with him. A witness recalled Durousseau hitting on a girl that appeared to be around 13 or 14 years old.<ref>{{cite web | last = Treen | first = Dana | title = Accused killer was lewd, say neighbors | work = jacksonville.com | publisher = The Florida Times-Union | date = 19 June 2003 | url =http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/061903/met_12829524.shtml | accessdate = }}</ref>
== Chronology of the murders == Less than one month after the [[acquittal]] over the rape charges, the nude body of 26-year-old Tracy Habersham was found on September 7, 1997 in [[Fort Benning]].<ref name="news4jax.com">{{cite web | title = Suspected Serial Killer Under Arrest | work = News4Jax.com | publisher = WJXT | date = 18 June 2003 | url = http://www.news4jax.com/news/2275524/detail.html | accessdate = | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100714151920/http://www.news4jax.com/news/2275524/detail.html | archivedate = 14 July 2010 | df = }}</ref> She had been missing for 48 hours and was last seen leaving a party. She had been [[rape]]d and [[strangulation|strangled]] to death with a cord. Durousseau was not a suspect in the murder, but [[DNA profiling|DNA]] would later tie him to the crime. He later confessed to Habersham's killing after his arrest.<ref name="jacksonville.com"/><ref>{{cite web | title = Serial murder suspect linked to 1997 murder in Columbus, Ga. | work = First Coast News | publisher = Gannett Broadcasting | date = 19 June 2003 | url = http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/news-article.aspx?storyid=5133 | accessdate = }}</ref>
In 1999, Durousseau raped and killed 24-year-old Tyresa Mack in her apartment. Witnesses saw him leave her place with a television.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pysih.com/paul-durousseau/ |title=Paul Durousseau |date=June 11, 2007 |website=pysih.com |publisher= |accessdate=October 10, 2014}}{{Verify credibility|date=April 2013}}</ref> In 2001, he was arrested for raping a young woman in Jacksonville. He spent 30 days in jail and received two years' [[probation]]. On December 19, 2002, 18-year-old Nicole L. Williams' body was found wrapped in a blue blanket at the bottom of a ditch in Jacksonville. She had been reported missing two days earlier.<ref name="news4jax.com"/>
On January 1, 2003, family members of 19-year-old Nikia Kilpatrick went to check on her. They had not had any news from her for several days. They found her body in the bedroom of her apartment. She had been raped then killed by strangulation with a cord two days before. Her two sons, an eleven-month-old and a two-year-old, were alive but [[Malnutrition|malnourished]]. Kilpatrick was approximately six months pregnant at the time of her death.<ref name="trutv.com" /> Eight days later, 20-year-old [[Certified Nurse Assistant|nurse assistant]] Shawanda Denise McCalister, who was also pregnant at the time of her death, was raped and strangled in her Jacksonville apartment. The murder scene was almost identical to that of Kilpatrick. She was killed on Durousseau's first day of driving a cab for Gator City Taxi. Her body was found the following day.
The next two victims were 17-year-old Jovanna Jefferson, and 19-year-old Surita Cohen. Their bodies were found close to each other in a ditch next to a construction site on New Kings Road in Jacksonville on February 5. Police estimated that Jefferson was murdered around January 20 and Cohen was killed 10 days later. Witnesses recount having seen the two last victims with a taxi driver fitting Paul Durousseau's description on the night they disappeared.
Durousseau was arrested and charged with five counts of murder on June 17, 2003. On December 13, 2007 he was [[death penalty|sentenced to death]] by [[lethal injection]] for the murder of Tyresa Mack. As of August 18, 2013, he was still a resident on Florida's death row at [[Union Correctional Institution]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Inmate Population Information Detail|url=http://www.dc.state.fl.us/activeinmates/detail.asp?Bookmark=1&From=list&SessionID=534230036|work=5/26/2013|publisher=Florida Department of Corrections|accessdate=28 May 2013}}</ref> In January 2017, Durousseau's death sentence was overturned by the [[Florida Supreme Court]].<ref>http://www.news4jax.com/news/florida-supreme-court-tosses-taxi-driver-killers-death-sentence</ref>
==See also== * [[List of death row inmates in the United States]]

[[File:Beinsa Duno.jpg|thumbnail|right|Peter Deunov]] '''Peter Deunov''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|ʌ|n|ɒ|v}} ({{lang-bg|Петър Дънов}}, {{IPA-bg|'pɛtər 'dɤnof|IPA}}; July 11, 1864 – December 27, 1944), also known by his spiritual name '''Beinsa Douno''' ({{lang-bg|Беинса Дуно}}, {{IPA-bg|bɛinˈsа duˈnɔ|}}), and often called the Master by his followers, was a [[Bulgaria]]n philosopher and spiritual teacher who developed a form of [[Esoteric Christianity]] known as the [[Universal White Brotherhood]]. He is widely known in Bulgaria, where he was voted second by the public in the ''Great Bulgarians'' TV show on Bulgarian National Television (2006-2007) after the [[BBC]] format.<ref name=BNT-100>Bulgarian National Television - "The Great Bulgarians", http://welcome.bnt.bg/movies/velikitebg.php?id=12, Accessed July 17, 2014</ref> Deunov is also featured in Pantev and Gavrilov's ''The 100 Most Influential Bulgarians in Our History'' (ranked in 37th place).<ref name=the-100>Pantev, A.L. and Gavrilov, B.G., ''The 100 Most Influential Bulgarians in Our History'' (in Bulgarian “100-те най-влиятелни българи в нашата история”), Reporter, 1997, Bulgaria, 328 pp., {{ISBN|9548102242}}, 9789548102247</ref> According to Petrov, Peter Deunov is “the most published Bulgarian author to this day.”<ref name=drews-history>Petrov, N., "Drew's Global Heritage: History of International Students", ''Peter Deunov: An Early Graduate from Bulgaria'', Drew Theological School, http://www.drew.edu/theological/2012/01/drews-global-heritage-history-of-international-students-at-drew-theological-school#bulgaria, Accessed 24 July 2014</ref>
== Biography ==
===Early life=== Peter Deunov was born in the village of Hadardja (now Nikolaevka in [[Suvorovo Municipality]]) near [[Varna]], [[Bulgaria]] on July 11, 1864, the third child of Konstantin Dunovsky and Dobra Atanasova Georgieva. His father was the first Bulgarian teacher in the region before becoming a Bulgarian [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] priest. He was one of the first to present the [[liturgy]] in Bulgarian, the language of the local people, rather than the traditional sacred language of Church Slavonic (Old Bulgarian).<ref name=Bio>Kraleva, M., ''The Master Peter Deunov: His Life and Teaching'', Kibea, 2001, Bulgaria; {{ISBN|954-47426-89}}</ref>
Deunov attended secondary school in [[Varna]] and the American [[Methodist]] School of Theology and Science in [[Svishtov]], from which he graduated in 1886. He worked as a primary school teacher for a year before leaving for the United States, where he studied theology at [[Drew Theological Seminary]] in [[Madison, New Jersey]], from 1888 to May 1892. After graduating from Drew, in the fall of 1892 he enrolled in the [[Boston University School of Theology]] and obtained his degree in June 1893 with a thesis on "The Migration of the Germanic Tribes and Their Christianisation" (published in 2007<ref name=thesis>Peter Dunoff, ''The Migration of the Teutonic Tribes and Their Conversion to Christianity: Boston University School of Theology Thesis, 1893'', St. Kliment Ohridski University Press, 2007, {{ISBN|978-954-07-2645-8}}</ref>). He was a regular student at the School of Medicine of [[Boston University]] for a year, before returning to Bulgaria in 1895.
=== Return to Bulgaria === Upon his return to Bulgaria Deunov was offered the position of a Methodist pastor in the city of [[Yambol]]. This offer was withdrawn after he stipulated he would only serve without remuneration. In 1896 he published ''Science and Education'', in which he analyzed the development of mankind into a new culture, which he thought was bound to take place during the forthcoming century. After the turn of the century, Deunov began to travel throughout Bulgaria for several years, giving talks and undertaking [[phrenology|phrenological research]].{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} He met with a wide circle of people. Among them were his first three disciples, who had belonged to different branches of Christianity – Todor Stoimenov ([[Eastern Orthodox]]), Dr. Mirkovich ([[Catholic]]) and Penyu Kirov ([[Protestant]]). After a long correspondence, all of them met in Varna during 19–23 July 1900. It is considered the first annual convention of what later became a spiritual community that lasted until the end of Deunov's life. Deunov eventually settled in [[Sofia]], the capital of Bulgaria, and began giving lectures.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
In 1914 he gave his first public lecture, ''Behold, the Man!'' (''Ecce Homo'' in Latin), published later in the series ''Power and Life''. Deunov began to give regular Sunday lectures which were based on the elaboration and explanation of a [[Biblical]] passage. [[File:Sofia-peter-deunov-grave-5.jpg|thumb|200px| Grave of Peter Deunov in "[[Izgrev, Sofia|Izgrev]]" estate, Sofia, Bulgaria ]] In 1921 the community ''Izgrev'' (Sunrise) was established. A site at what were then the outskirts of Sofia, it was the gathering place in the mornings for Deunov and his disciples. Many followers started building nearby and the place eventually became the center of a large spiritual community. Deunov gave lectures in the newly constructed Lecture Hall. In 1922 he initiated two new streams of specialized lectures in addition to the Sunday lectures, and from 1930 began delivering “morning talks” on Sunday mornings before dawn. The themes of the different lecture streams were wide-ranging and encompassed, among others: [[religion]], [[music]], [[geometry]], [[astrology]], [[philosophy]] and [[esotericism|esoteric science]]. Overall, Deunov gave approximately 3700 lectures in the three decades between 1914 and 1944. His thoughts were also recorded in talks, private conversations, and early letters.<ref name=catalog>Kovachev, T., ''The Master Beinsa Douno: A catalog of the lectures, prayers, musical exercises, Paneurhythmy, gymnastic exercises (1896-1944)'' (in Bulgarian, “Учителя Беинса Дуно. Справочник на беседите и лекциите, молитвите, музикалните упражнения, Паневритмията, гимнастическите упражнения (1896–1944)”), 2004, Sofia, Bulgaria; {{ISBN|954-9589-84-6}}</ref>
=== Paneurhythmy === [[File:Panevritmia do Babreka.jpg|alt= Paneurhythmy being performed near Bubreka (Kidney) lake in Rila|thumb|Paneurhythmy near Bubreka (Kidney) lake in [[Rila]]|left|187x187px]]
In 1932, he developed Paneurhythmy exercises: a sequence of exercises performed to music, to achieve inner balance and harmonization. This practice promotes the processes of self-perfecting, expanding of the consciousness and attaining of virtues. The circle dance, is a conscious interchange between human beings and the forces of living nature. Each movement is the expression of a thought. The effect should be that the observer picks up from the movements, the thought or the idea they express. The rhythm in the movement of the physical body leads us to one in our spiritual life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3rZTiZbTYeUWAN_EXBihgi4wqwFTXoXz|title=Paneurhythmy - video tutorial 2007 - YouTube|website=YouTube|language=en|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref>
Etymologically, "Pan-Eu-Rhythmy" is derived from three roots: *Pan - meaning Whole; Universal and Cosmic. *Eu - meaning True or Supreme; the essential and substantial in the world. *Rhythmy - meaning correctness in the movements and in every other external expression in life.
=== Late life === On March 22, 1939 he wrote a message to his disciples entitled "The Eternal Covenant of the Spirit." At the beginning of 1944, during the air bombardments over Sofia, he organized the evacuation to the village of [[Marchaevo]] (24 km southwest of Sofia) and settled in the home (now museum) of his pupil [[Temelko Gyorev]]. He returned to [[Izgrev, Sofia|Izgrev]] on October 19, 1944. On December 20, 1944, he delivered the lecture "The Last Word" to the Common Occult Class and passed away on 27 December.<ref name="paneurhythmy">''Beinsa Douno: Paneurhythmy - Music, Ideas, Movements (step by step description)'', Bialo Bratstvo Publishers, 2004, Sofia, Bulgaria.<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --></ref>
== Legacy == Several thousand of Deunov's lectures were recorded by stenographers and are documented in the form of deciphered [[stenography|stenograms]] (some modified by editing and others left intact <ref name=topic2>Christophorus, Answers on important topics, ''Topic 2: About the original Word of the Master Peter Deunov (Beinsa Douno)'', http://www.beinsa-douno.net/important-topics.html#topic2_original_Word, Accessed July 17, 2014</ref>). These contain the essence of Deunov's teaching. There are also a number of songs and prayers, among which ''The Good Prayer'' from 1900 is regarded as the most special.<ref name=Bio/>
*[[Albert Einstein]] famously said "''The whole world bows down before me. I bow down before the master Peter Deunov''".<ref name="How One Man Saved Bulgaria's Jews">{{Cite news|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/21978/how-one-man-saved-bulgarias-jews|title=How One Man Saved Bulgaria's Jews|date=2009-06-15|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Prophet-Our-Times-Teachings-Deunov-ebook/dp/B00Z6W0BII|title=Prophet for Our Times: The Life and Teachings of Peter Deunov|last=Lorimer|first=Peter|date=2015-09-08|publisher=Hay House UK|editor-last=Lorimer|editor-first=David|language=English}}</ref> *[[Pope John XXIII]] called Peter Deunov "''the greatest philosopher living on the Earth''".<ref name="How One Man Saved Bulgaria's Jews"/>{{Better source|date=August 2018}}

== Further reading == * ''The Wellspring of Good: The Last Words of the Master Peter Deunov'', Compiled by Bojan Boev and Boris Nikolov, Kibea Publishing Company, 2002. * David Lorimer, ed. ''Gems of Love and Wisdom – Prayers, Meditations and Reflections by Beinsa Douno (Peter Deunov)''. Element Books Ltd, 1991. * {{cite book|author=Milka Kraleva|title=The master: Peter Deunov, his life and teaching|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OJBAAQAAIAAJ|date=2001|publisher=Kibea|isbn=978-954-474-268-3}} * Ardella Nathanael. ''Dance of the Soul: Peter Deunov’s Pan-Eu-Rhythmy,'' Carlsbad, CA, Esoteric Publishing, 2006. * Ardella Nathanael. ''The Butterfly Dance: Peter Deunov’s PanEuRhythmy,'' San Rafael, CA, CreateSpace, 2010.
== External links == * [http://www.beinsadouno.org/en Society of the White Brotherhood, Bulgaria] (English version) Official website - biographical details, brief information about Deunov's teaching, forums (Bulgarian only), and other resources. * [http://www.beinsa-douno.net The English Master Peter Deunov (Beinsa Douno) Home Page] - English translations of lectures, prayers and other works by Deunov from authentic sources, as well as discussions of various topics related to his life and teaching. * [http://www.powerandlife.com ''Power and Life''] - in several languages, with translations of lectures sourced from around the Internet. * [http://panevritmia.info/?lang=en Paneurhythmy] - comprehensive site with background information and videos.
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Rod Lyon''' was born in [[Cornwall]] and trained as a civil engineer.<ref name="Tewennow">{{cite web|url=http://www.gorsethkernow.org.uk/english/gallery/grandbards/etewenn.htm|title=Rod Lyon (Tewennow)|publisher=[[Cornish Gorseth]]|accessdate=29 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819202316/http://www.gorsethkernow.org.uk/english/gallery/grandbards/etewenn.htm|archivedate=19 August 2008|df=}}</ref> After spending some early years at sea, he worked until retirement as a Local Government Officer.<ref name="Tewennow"/> He was the Grand Bard of the [[Gorseth Kernow]] between 2003-2006 with the [[bardic name]] of "Tewennow".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gorsethkernow.org.uk/english/gallery/grandbards/gallbard.htm|title=Gallery of Grand Bards|publisher=[[Gorseth Kernow]]|accessdate=29 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830010809/http://www.gorsethkernow.org.uk/english/gallery/grandbards/gallbard.htm|archivedate=30 August 2009|df=}}</ref> His involvement in [[Cornwall|Cornish]] matters revolves mainly around the development of the [[Cornish language]], which includes work on the radio and writing. He sits on the [[Cornish Language Board]], the Cornish Eisteddfod and various committees within and associated with the Gorseth. Lyon can be heard at 5pm every Sunday reading the news in Cornish on BBC Radio Cornwall.
==References== <references/>

{{cornwall-stub}}
